trans-unit.source: Get started with Azure Notification Hubs | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Get started with Azure Notification Hubs | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you learn how to use Azure Notification Hubs to send push notifications to a Kindle application.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you learn how to use Azure Notification Hubs to send push notifications to a Kindle application.

trans-unit.source: Get started with Notification Hubs
trans-unit.target: Get started with Notification Hubs

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use Azure Notification Hubs to send push notifications to a Kindle application.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use Azure Notification Hubs to send push notifications to a Kindle application.

trans-unit.source: You'll create a blank Kindle app that receives push notifications by using Amazon Device Messaging (ADM).
trans-unit.target: You'll create a blank Kindle app that receives push notifications by using Amazon Device Messaging (ADM).

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires the following:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires the following:

trans-unit.source: Get the Android SDK (we assume that you will use Eclipse) from the <html></html>Android site<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: Get the Android SDK (we assume that you will use Eclipse) from the <html></html>Android site<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in <html></html>Setting Up Your Development Environment<html></html> to set up your development environment for Kindle.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in <html></html>Setting Up Your Development Environment<html></html> to set up your development environment for Kindle.

trans-unit.source: Add a new app to the developer portal
trans-unit.target: Add a new app to the developer portal

trans-unit.source: First, create an app in the [Amazon developer portal].
trans-unit.target: First, create an app in the [Amazon developer portal].

trans-unit.source: Copy the Application Key.
trans-unit.target: Copy the Application Key.

trans-unit.source: In the portal, click the name of your app, and then click the Device Messaging tab.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, click the name of your app, and then click the Device Messaging tab.

trans-unit.source: Click Create a New Security Profile, and then create a new security profile (for example, TestAdm security profile).
trans-unit.target: Click Create a New Security Profile, and then create a new security profile (for example, TestAdm security profile).

trans-unit.source: Then click Save.
trans-unit.target: Then click Save.

trans-unit.source: Click Security Profiles to view the security profile that you just created.
trans-unit.target: Click Security Profiles to view the security profile that you just created.

trans-unit.source: Copy the Client ID and Client Secret values for later use.
trans-unit.target: Copy the Client ID and Client Secret values for later use.

trans-unit.source: Create an API key
trans-unit.target: Create an API key

trans-unit.source: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges.
trans-unit.target: Open a command prompt with administrator privileges.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the Android SDK folder.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the Android SDK folder.

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: For the keystore password, type android.
trans-unit.target: For the keystore password, type android.

trans-unit.source: Copy the MD5 fingerprint.
trans-unit.target: Copy the MD5 fingerprint.

trans-unit.source: Back in the developer portal, on the Messaging tab, click Android/Kindle and enter the name of the package for your app (for example, com.sample.notificationhubtest) and the MD5 value, and then click Generate API Key.
trans-unit.target: Back in the developer portal, on the Messaging tab, click Android/Kindle and enter the name of the package for your app (for example, com.sample.notificationhubtest) and the MD5 value, and then click Generate API Key.

trans-unit.source: Add credentials to the hub
trans-unit.target: Add credentials to the hub

trans-unit.source: In the portal, add the client secret and client ID to the Configure tab of your notification hub.
trans-unit.target: In the portal, add the client secret and client ID to the Configure tab of your notification hub.

trans-unit.source: Set up your application
trans-unit.target: Set up your application

trans-unit.source: When you're creating an application, use at least API Level 17.
trans-unit.target: When you're creating an application, use at least API Level 17.

trans-unit.source: Add the ADM libraries to your Eclipse project:
trans-unit.target: Add the ADM libraries to your Eclipse project:

trans-unit.source: To obtain the ADM library, [download the SDK].
trans-unit.target: To obtain the ADM library, [download the SDK].

trans-unit.source: Extract the SDK zip file.
trans-unit.target: Extract the SDK zip file.

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse, right-click your project, and then click Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse, right-click your project, and then click Properties.

trans-unit.source: Select Java Build Path on the left, and then select the *Libraries *tab at the top.
trans-unit.target: Select Java Build Path on the left, and then select the *Libraries *tab at the top.

trans-unit.source: Click Add External Jar, and select the file \SDK\Android\DeviceMessaging\lib\amazon-device-messaging-*.jar from the directory in which you extracted the Amazon SDK.
trans-unit.target: Click Add External Jar, and select the file \SDK\Android\DeviceMessaging\lib\amazon-device-messaging-*.jar from the directory in which you extracted the Amazon SDK.

trans-unit.source: Download the NotificationHubs Android SDK (link).
trans-unit.target: Download the NotificationHubs Android SDK (link).

trans-unit.source: Unzip the package, and then drag the file notification-hubs-sdk.jar into the libs folder in Eclipse.
trans-unit.target: Unzip the package, and then drag the file notification-hubs-sdk.jar into the libs folder in Eclipse.

trans-unit.source: Edit your app manifest to support ADM:
trans-unit.target: Edit your app manifest to support ADM:

trans-unit.source: Add the Amazon namespace in the root manifest element:
trans-unit.target: Add the Amazon namespace in the root manifest element:

trans-unit.source: Add permissions as the first element under the manifest element.
trans-unit.target: Add permissions as the first element under the manifest element.

trans-unit.source: Substitute [YOUR PACKAGE NAME] with the package that you used to create your app.
trans-unit.target: Substitute [YOUR PACKAGE NAME] with the package that you used to create your app.

trans-unit.source: Insert the following element as the first child of the application element.
trans-unit.target: Insert the following element as the first child of the application element.

trans-unit.source: Remember to substitute [YOUR SERVICE NAME] with the name of your ADM message handler that you create in the next section (including the package), and replace [YOUR PACKAGE NAME] with the package name with which you created your app.
trans-unit.target: Remember to substitute [YOUR SERVICE NAME] with the name of your ADM message handler that you create in the next section (including the package), and replace [YOUR PACKAGE NAME] with the package name with which you created your app.

trans-unit.source: Create your ADM message handler
trans-unit.target: Create your ADM message handler

trans-unit.source: Create a new class that inherits from com.amazon.device.messaging.ADMMessageHandlerBase and name it MyADMMessageHandler, as shown in the following figure:
trans-unit.target: Create a new class that inherits from com.amazon.device.messaging.ADMMessageHandlerBase and name it MyADMMessageHandler, as shown in the following figure:

trans-unit.target: Add the following import statements:

trans-unit.target: Add the following code in the class that you created.

trans-unit.target: Remember to substitute the hub name and connection string (listen):

trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the OnMessage() method:

trans-unit.source: Add your API key to your app
trans-unit.target: Add your API key to your app

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse, create a new file named api_key.txt in the directory assets of your project.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse, create a new file named api_key.txt in the directory assets of your project.

trans-unit.source: Open the file and copy the API key that you generated in the Amazon developer portal.
trans-unit.target: Open the file and copy the API key that you generated in the Amazon developer portal.

trans-unit.source: Run the app
trans-unit.target: Run the app

trans-unit.source: Start the emulator.
trans-unit.target: Start the emulator.

trans-unit.source: In the emulator, swipe from the top and click Settings, and then click My account and register with a valid Amazon account.
trans-unit.target: In the emulator, swipe from the top and click Settings, and then click My account and register with a valid Amazon account.

trans-unit.source: In Eclipse, run the app.
trans-unit.target: In Eclipse, run the app.

trans-unit.source: If a problem occurs, check the time of the emulator (or device).
trans-unit.target: If a problem occurs, check the time of the emulator (or device).

trans-unit.source: The time value must be accurate.
trans-unit.target: The time value must be accurate.

trans-unit.source: To change the time of the Kindle emulator, you can run the following command from your Android SDK platform-tools directory:
trans-unit.target: To change the time of the Kindle emulator, you can run the following command from your Android SDK platform-tools directory:
